results.title: Merce Cunningham & Company
results.creator_credit: Benoit Jacquot, Cunningham Dance Foundation and L'Institut National de L'Audiovisuel (INA)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merce Cunningham Dance Company = Cunningham Dance Foundation”.
This documentary explores Merce Cunningham’s method of choreography, including his employment of random methods through use of the I Ching, his collaboration with composer John Cage and his relationship with the dancers in his Company. Cunningham candidly reveals his ideas on dance through interviews, and footage from rehearsal at the Cunningham studios. Included are dance excerpts from “Trails,” “Scramble,” “Aeon,” “Quartet”, “Suite For Five”, “Roadrunners” and “Fractions”. In English with French with English subtitles. Reference: http://www.merce.org/filmvideo.html
results.creator_credit_for_label: Benoit Jacquot, Cunningham Dance Foundation and L’Institut National de L’Audiovisuel (INA)

results.title: Amy
results.creator_credit: Nadia Tass, David Parker, Cascade Films and Film Victoria
results.brief_description: Since witnessing the traumatic death of her rock-star father three years earlier, eight-year-old Amy has become mute and deaf, despite doctors declaring her physically fit. Her mother, struggling to make ends meet since the death of her husband, and determined to keep Amy out of the school system, has moved with her daughter to a remote farmhouse. When child welfare officers insist that Amy must return to the city to attend a school for the deaf, mother and daughter flee to the anonymity of a shabby working-class suburb in Melbourne populated by losers and misfits. Amongst this quirky cast of characters (the likes of which were a characteristic element of Australian features of the early nineties including Parker and Tass’ earlier work), they meet a young drop-out musician who finds a way to connect with Amy through music, allowing her to regain her voice through song. Despite a strong cast, the film suffers from an attempt to embrace a range of genres and styles including slapstick comedy, musical, family melodrama and gritty realism. Cast includes Alana De Roma, Rachel Griffiths, Ben Mendelsohn, Nick Barker and Kerry Armstrong.

results.title: The League of gentlemen
results.creator_credit: Basil Dearden, Michael Relph and Allied Filmmakers
results.brief_description: A disgruntled army colonel who has been forcibly retired decides to take revenge on England by executing a daring daylight bank robbery. To undertake the crime he commandeers seven ex-army men who have fallen foul of the law in some way or other. The eight men (who don’t know each other) treat the assignment like a reconnaissance mission, carefully planned under the leadership of Colonel Hyde. “The League of gentlemen” is an old-fashioned caper movie that moves exceptionally well through the stages of the crime: the initial research, the preparations, the raid for ammunition, the day of the heist, the aftermath. The film also serves as a timepiece for England in the late 1950s - the last dregs of post-war hang-ups, the loosening of morals and hints of the swinging 60s, the displacement of these men who have moved from the heroism of their war years to shady existences. Adapted from the novel by John Boland, “The League of Gentlemen” has a pacey and witty script that is buoyed by fine performances from Jack Hawkins, Nigel Patrick, Roger Livesey and Richard Attenborough.

results.title: Lantana
results.creator_credit: Ray Lawrence, Jan Chapman, Film Finance Corporation Australia, MBP and Saddleback Productions
results.brief_description: Ray Lawrence (Bliss) returned to filmmaking after a sixteen-year absence to direct “Lantana”. Adapted from his own play, scriptwriter Andrew Bovell depicts a dozen characters, reflecting a prism of modern day Sydney. One woman’s death - perhaps murder - sparks a crisis in a series on interconnecting relationships. Leon is a policeman investigating the woman’s disappearance, who’s emotional stolidity is reflected in his violent dealings with clients; his aging wife Sonja seeks counselling for her desolate personal state; her therapist Valerie, is struggling to cope with the death of her teenage daughter and the deterioration of her marriage to John, an emotionally remote academic; Jane, a lonely and aimless woman, is estranged from her husband Pete and seeks sex with Leon. Miscommunication and secret trysts (real and imagined) leads characters to draw false conclusions. Several red herrings increase the intensity of the murder mystery, but the real concern of the film is the kaleidoscope of human failings and interactions, reflecting a complex interweaving of intent and desire. Paul Kelly’s score serves as an effective moody soundtrack to the film. Winner of eight AFI awards. Cinematography by Mandy Walker. Cast includes Anthony La Paglia, Geoffrey Rush, Barbara Hershey, Kerry Armstrong, Rachael Blake, Vince Colosimo, Peter Phelps, Leah Purcell, Glenn Robins.

results.title: The Anniversary party
results.creator_credit: Alan Cumming, Jennifer Jason Leigh, Joanne Sellar, Fine Line Features and Pas de Quoi
results.brief_description: The Anniversary party was co-directed, co-written and co-produced by actors Alan Cumming and Jennifer Jason Leigh, marking the latter’s directorial debut. The story centres on a married couple (Leigh and Cumming), who decide to hold a party to celebrate their sixth wedding anniversary. She is an aging actress past her prime; he is a writer set to direct the film version of his novel. Over the course of the day and the night guests come and go, consisting of friends, colleagues and neighbours, mostly Hollywood types involved in the film industry in some way or another. Having only recently re-united after a tumultuous period, both partners are to a degree on edge and eager to display the stability of their union. The status quo becomes increasingly tested over the course of the soiree as revelations threaten to destroy their re-established happiness. Having collaborated on the script for several years the two directors conceived the film as a low budget ensemble comedy/drama and this feature was originally shot on video. Stars: Alan Cumming, Jennifer Jason Leigh, Kevin Klein, Jane Adams, Phoebe Cates, John C. Reilly, Parker Posey, Gwyneth Paltrow and Jennifer Beals.

results.title: Storm Boy [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Henri Safran, Matt Carroll and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Three characters live in isolation amidst the coastal sand dunes of the Coorong in southern South Australia. In a shack on the beach live Tom, a fisherman, and his young son; out amongst the dunes lives a First Nations man, ‘Fingerbone Bill’, who forms a friendship with the boy, naming him ‘Storm Boy’. The story is conveyed with simplicity, with events being left unspoken and undetailed. The relationships between the characters, and the scenes where the boy and his pet pelican play together are subtly sketched. Burton’s photography effectively captures the wild beauty of the Coorong.

results.title: The Fall of the Roman Empire
results.creator_credit: Anthony Mann, Samuel Bronston and Samuel Bronston Productions
results.brief_description: In second century Rome Emperor Marcus Aurelius plans to make the heir to the throne his adopted son Livius, rather than his biological son Commodus. Indignant with rage, Commodus has his father murdered and succeeds him, declaring himself a God. When Commodus discovers that his sister, Lucilla has a stronger claim to the throne than he, Commodus sentences her to burn at the stake. This sword-and-sandal epic harked back to successful 1950s biblical dramas with its lavish sets, scores of extras, remarkable action sequences and a chariot race. The exorbitant cost of the film (and poor audience reception) financially ruined producer Samuel Bronston. It has been speculated that audiences were tiring of such lavish productions and timing may have also hurt the film’s box-office - it was released the same year as the opulent Burton/Taylor epic “Cleopatra”. Cast includes Sophia Loren, Christopher Plummer, Alec Guinness, Omar Sharif and James Mason.

constellations_other.name: Swords, sandals and lightning bolts
constellations_other.description: In Thor: Love and Thunder, Russell Crowe plays one of the most recogniseable gods in the pantheon – Zeus. His scenes lampoon his Oscar-winning role in Gladiator, one of the most recognised films in a classic genre.

results.title: Let's get Skase
results.creator_credit: Matthew George, Colin South, John Tatoulis, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Lotteries Commission of Western Australia, Media World Features and ScreenWest
results.brief_description: A quirky adventure-comedy based on the alleged “true story” of one man’s attempt to kidnap failed Australian businessman Christopher Skase. When Peter Dellasandro (Lachy Hulme) convinces the creditors of the Quintex Empire to fund a covert mission to send a crack team of experts to Majorca to kidnap Skase and return him to Australia things don’t go quite as he planned. What his crack team of misfits lack in skill, they make up for in enthusiasm. Cast includes Craig McLachlan, who stars as Eric Carney, host of a reality TV program who is mounting his own mission to ‘get Skase’, and Alex Dimitriades as Danny D’Amato, Dellasandro’s right-hand man.

results.title: Ali
results.creator_credit: Michael Mann, A. Kitman Ho, James Lassiter, Jon Peters, Paul Ardaji and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Michael Mann’s sprawling bio pic tries to cover big ground with this iconoclastic boxing figure. The results are more like a greatest hits as Mann tracks Ali’s rise in the boxing world and his status as a potent force in black politics. Will Smith inhabits the towering frame of Ali quite convincingly, turning in a performance which is more like a collage of Ali sound bytes. Along the way we become privy to some of the most influential and turbulent political movements in America; through Ali’s controversial association with activist Malcolm X, his conversion to Islam and his uncompromising anti-Vietnam war stance. While less savory aspects of Ali’s life (like his notorious womanizing) are left pretty much alone. Ali also draws on the mythical boxing match ‘Rumble in the jungle’ which was also the subject of the compelling documentary ‘When we were kings’. Cast includes: Jada Pinkett Smith, Jamie Foxx, Ron Silver, Jon Voight, Mario Van Peebles, Jeffrey Wright.

results.title: Mulholland Drive
results.creator_credit: David Lynch, Alain Sarde, Mary Sweeney, Michael Polaire, Neal Edelstein, Tony Krantz, Asymmetrical Productions, Imagine Television, Les Films Alain Sarde, Picture Factory and Studio Canal+
results.brief_description: Betty Elms (Naomi Watts) has arrived in Hollywood dreaming of being a star. But when she goes to stay at her Aunt’s apartment she finds it occupied by the lovely Rita (Laura Elena Harring) who has lost her memory and is terrified for her life. From the most basic of plots and narrative cliche, David Lynch furnishes a deeply troubling and deeply erotic investigation of Hollywood, a vision which has the logic and texture of a hallucinatory dream. Both Betty and Rita, and their alter egos, Diane and Camilla, embody competing versions of celebrity and fame: movies as success and Hollywood as destruction. But attempting to explain “Mulholland Drive” in linear terms is self-defeating. A continuation of Lynch’s ground-breaking work in “Blue Velvet”, “Twin Peaks” and “Lost Highway”, the surreal sequences in the film are never excessively melodramatic or ridiculous; they are often moving and chilling. Lynch creates a singularly impressive mise-en-scene of the unconscious which places him in the forefront of contemporary cinema. “Mulholland Drive” began as a pilot for a TV series. When the producers were alarmed by Lynch’s work, they cancelled the series. Fortunately, Lynch was able to eventually secure funding from European production sources. But this difficult genesis and production history has been written into the final film itself, where the Machiavellian game which is filmmaking in Hollywood is re-cast in stark visual metaphors of good and of evil. In Lynch’s universe, the Devil is a cowboy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Lynch, Alain Sarde, Mary Sweeney, Michael Polaire, Neal Edelstein, Tony Krantz, Asymmetrical Productions, Imagine Television, Les Films Alain Sarde, Picture Factory and Studio Canal+
